Description: Fragment of terracotta figurine of a bare-chested youth Harpokrates enthroned. Head with sidelock and upper body. Right hand raised touching the sidelock, part of this missing. Left arm with hand at his side. Mould-made. Solid; light brown-beige micaceous clay. Thick white accretion with pink surface in crevices, possibly remains of an overall coating?
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Enthroned ithyphallic Harpocrates with one hand raised. This type was originally produced during the Late Period as a solid figure (British Museum GR 1973,0501.16 and in stone GR2011,5011.15; Cambridge Fitzwilliam, E.81.1914, Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology, NA596) and was subsequently made hollow in the 3rd century BC like other Ptolemaic figures (Bolton Museum 1886.31.23; British Museum GR 1973,0501.56; GR1973,0501.10; GR1973,0501.74). Close parallel (same mould-series?) from 3rd century BC Ras el Soda, Alexandria (Himmelmann 1983, 47, 59, pl.23a; Adriani 1952). Close parallels for the Ptolemaic type were found at Panopolis (?) (Breccia 1934, no. 173; LIMC 8 (2), pl. 693:162), dated late 1st century BC (Skupinska-Løvset 1978, no. UT 117) and unprovenanced (Van Wijngaarden 1958, no. 16). Similar parallels have been dated late Hellenistic (Fischer 1994, no. 562), from the Fayum (Weber 1914, no. 42 and 43) and unprovenanced (Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991, no. 25). One parallel was dated to the Roman period (Dunand 1990, no. 221), though the figurines from the workshop at Naukratis fit into the period 3rd to 2nd century BC (Bailey 2008).
